stem:
The patient's clinical presentation suggests a possible increase in intracranial pressure (ICP). Based on the provided data, select the most appropriate intervention for each assessment finding below.

Decreased level of consciousness: [dropdown1]
Systolic blood pressure trending upwards with widening pulse pressure: [dropdown2]
Pupil asymmetry: [dropdown3]

itemContext.sbar:
S: Jameson Tyrell is a 68-year-old male admitted three days ago for an acute ischemic stroke affecting the right middle cerebral artery. He's currently in the ICU.
B: His past medical history includes hypertension, atrial fibrillation (managed with warfarin), and hyperlipidemia. His initial NIHSS score upon admission was 18, indicating a significant neurological deficit.
A: At 0600 this morning, Mr. Tyrell's Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score is 10 (E2, V3, M5), a decline from 14 at 0200. His right pupil is 5mm and sluggishly reactive, while his left pupil is 3mm and reactive. His blood pressure is 180/70 mmHg, heart rate is 88 bpm, respiratory rate is 12 breaths per minute, and SpO2 is 97% on 2L nasal cannula. The neurosurgeon was notified of these changes at 0615.
R: I am highly concerned about a potential increase in intracranial pressure (ICP) given the patient's declining GCS, pupil changes, and blood pressure trends. I am requesting orders for mannitol to help reduce ICP and a repeat CT scan of the head to assess for any worsening edema or hemorrhage. I also need guidance on optimal blood pressure management in the context of potential increased ICP, as well as clarification on the appropriate head of bed positioning. All relevant labs and vital signs are readily available in the electronic health record (EHR). Please advise.

tabs.title: Labs
tabs.content: Na: 140 mEq/L, K: 4.1 mEq/L, Cl: 100 mEq/L, BUN: 20 mg/dL, Creatinine: 1.1 mg/dL, INR: 2.5, PT: 28 seconds, PTT: 45 seconds, Glucose: 110 mg/dL, Platelets: 180,000/uL

tabs.title: MAR
tabs.content:
Warfarin 5mg PO daily, scheduled 0900
Lisinopril 20mg PO daily, scheduled 0900
Atorvastatin 40mg PO daily, scheduled 2100
PRN: Acetaminophen 650mg PO q4h for headache
PRN: Ondansetron 4mg IV q6h for nausea

rationale.correct:
Decreased level of consciousness: Implement seizure precautions.
Systolic blood pressure trending upwards with widening pulse pressure: Elevate the head of the bed to 30 degrees.
Pupil asymmetry: Prepare for immediate CT scan of the head.
rationale.incorrect:
Decreased level of consciousness: Administer a bolus of normal saline. (This could worsen cerebral edema).
Decreased level of consciousness: Lower the head of the bed. (This increases ICP).
Systolic blood pressure trending upwards with widening pulse pressure: Administer PRN Ondansetron. (While nausea can occur, addressing the blood pressure and ICP is priority).
Systolic blood pressure trending upwards with widening pulse pressure: Prepare for lumbar puncture. (Lumbar puncture is contraindicated with increased ICP due to risk of herniation).
Pupil asymmetry: Reassess pupils in 1 hour. (This delays critical intervention).
Pupil asymmetry: Increase oxygen flow rate to 6L NC. (While oxygenation is important, it doesn't address the underlying cause of pupil asymmetry).
clinicalPearls: Early recognition of increased ICP is crucial to prevent permanent neurological damage.
Hypertension in the setting of increased ICP may be the body's attempt to maintain cerebral perfusion pressure (CPP). Rapidly lowering blood pressure can be detrimental.
Pupil asymmetry is a late sign of increased ICP and warrants immediate investigation.

questionTrap.trap: The question trap lies in prioritizing interventions for individual symptoms without considering the underlying cause (increased ICP). For example, focusing solely on the elevated blood pressure without addressing the ICP could lead to inappropriate treatment.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: To overcome this trap, analyze all the assessment findings together to identify the common underlying problem (increased ICP) and then select interventions that address that problem holistically.

mnemonic.title: I-C-P
mnemonic.expansion: Irritability (early sign), Changes in LOC, Pupils (unequal/sluggish)
